items.title: François Bayrou ousted as French PM after losing confidence vote
items.standfirst: Government collapses after Emmanuel Macron’s ally wins support of just 194 MPs with 364 against François Bayrou has been ousted in a confidence vote after only nine months as prime minister, collapsing his minority government and plunging France into a political crisis.Bayrou, 74, will hand his resignation to Emmanuel Macron, his longterm centrist ally, on Tuesday morning. Continue reading...
items.content: Government collapses after Emmanuel Macron’s ally wins support of just 194 MPs with 364 against François Bayrou has been ousted in a confidence vote after only nine months as prime minister, collapsing his minority government and plunging France into a political crisis.Bayrou, 74, will hand his resignation to Emmanuel Macron, his longterm centrist ally, on Tuesday morning. Continue reading...

items.title: French PM Bayrou loses confidence vote
items.standfirst: France’s parliament voted to topple the government of Prime Minister François Bayrou on Monday after the PM surprised even his own allies by calling a confidence vote to resolve a months-long deadlock over his austerity budget. Bayrou will tender his resignation on Tuesday morning, plunging France into fresh political turmoil.
items.content: France’s parliament voted to topple the government of Prime Minister François Bayrou on Monday after the PM surprised even his own allies by calling a confidence vote to resolve a months-long deadlock over his austerity budget. Bayrou will tender his resignation on Tuesday morning, plunging France into fresh political turmoil.

items.title: French Prime Minister François Bayrou ousted after losing confidence vote
items.standfirst: France's Prime Minister François Bayrou overwhelmingly lost a confidence vote Monday after nine months in office. CBS News correspondent Shanelle Kaul has more.
items.content: France's Prime Minister François Bayrou overwhelmingly lost a confidence vote Monday after nine months in office. CBS News correspondent Shanelle Kaul has more.

items.title: Macron to name new French prime minister after government collapse
Who will Macron appoint as next PM after Bayrou ousted?
items.standfirst: Legislators toppled France’s government in a confidence vote on Monday, a new crisis for Europe’s second-largest economy that obliges President Emmanuel Macron to search for a fourth prime minister in 12 months. But who that replacement will be remains unclear. France 24's Clovis Casali discusses what Macron might do next with Green Party MP Nicolas Bonnet.
items.content: Legislators toppled France’s government in a confidence vote on Monday, a new crisis for Europe’s second-largest economy that obliges President Emmanuel Macron to search for a fourth prime minister in 12 months. But who that replacement will be remains unclear. France 24's Clovis Casali discusses what Macron might do next with Green Party MP Nicolas Bonnet.

items.title: 'A victory for the French people' as Bayrou's government toppled
items.standfirst: Claire Lejeune, a French MP and member of the far-left France Unbowed, tells France 24's Clovis Casali that the toppling of prime minister François Bayrou's government in a confidence vote Monday was a "victory for the French people" as his government had "no democratic legitimacy".
items.content: Claire Lejeune, a French MP and member of the far-left France Unbowed, tells France 24's Clovis Casali that the toppling of prime minister François Bayrou's government in a confidence vote Monday was a "victory for the French people" as his government had "no democratic legitimacy".

items.title: France's government collapses after the prime minister loses a confidence vote
items.standfirst: Legislators toppled France's government in a confidence vote, a new crisis for Europe's second-largest economy. Prime Minister François Bayrou was ousted overwhelmingly in a 364-194 vote against him.
items.content: Legislators toppled France's government in a confidence vote, a new crisis for Europe's second-largest economy. Prime Minister François Bayrou was ousted overwhelmingly in a 364-194 vote against him.(Image credit: Christophe Ena)

items.content: France's parliament voted on Monday to bring down the government over its plans to tame the ballooning national debt, deepening a political crisis and handing President Emmanuel Macron the task of finding a fifth prime minister in less than two years.

items.title: Bayrou’s fall and a divided parliament hardly offer the stability Macron needs
items.standfirst: The French president will have to choose a new prime minister after resistance to austerity budget unites left and far-right in oppositionEurope live – latest updatesAs the French president, Emmanuel Macron, faces a crucial moment on the international stage this month, with the recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN assembly and diplomacy over Gaza and Ukraine, he has once again been shaken by a damaging political crisis at home.The centrist prime minister, François Bayrou, was toppled on Monday night in a parliamentary confidence vote, leaving Macron scrambling to appoint his third prime minister in a year, and the fifth since his second term as president began in 2022. Continue reading...
items.content: The French president will have to choose a new prime minister after resistance to austerity budget unites left and far-right in oppositionEurope live – latest updatesAs the French president, Emmanuel Macron, faces a crucial moment on the international stage this month, with the recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN assembly and diplomacy over Gaza and Ukraine, he has once again been shaken by a damaging political crisis at home.The centrist prime minister, François Bayrou, was toppled on Monday night in a parliamentary confidence vote, leaving Macron scrambling to appoint his third prime minister in a year, and the fifth since his second term as president began in 2022. items.title: 🔴 Live: French PM Bayrou's government toppled in confidence vote, plunging France into renewed crisis
France no-confidence vote: Le Pen urges Macron to call snap legislative polls
items.standfirst: French far-right three-time presidential candidate Marine Le Pen on Monday urged President Emmanuel Macron to call snap legislative elections in a bid to end months of political deadlock as the country's parliament prepared to cast ballots in a no-confidence vote. France 24's French politics editor Marc Perelman takes a closer look at the president's option if, as expected, the government is toppled.
items.content: French far-right three-time presidential candidate Marine Le Pen on Monday urged President Emmanuel Macron to call snap legislative elections in a bid to end months of political deadlock as the country's parliament prepared to cast ballots in a no-confidence vote. France 24's French politics editor Marc Perelman takes a closer look at the president's option if, as expected, the government is toppled.

items.title: A look back at Bayrou's nine-months as French PM
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister Francois Bayrou was set to fall in a confidence vote in parliament on Monday, bringing an end to a 9-month spell as head of the French government, but one that was never likely to be plain sailing.
items.content: French Prime Minister Francois Bayrou was set to fall in a confidence vote in parliament on Monday, bringing an end to a 9-month spell as head of the French government, but one that was never likely to be plain sailing.

items.title: 'Very little suspense as to what will happen next' as French PM set to lose confidence vote
items.standfirst: Eleonore Caroit, MP for French citizens living in Latin America and the Caribbean and a member of Emmanuel Macron's Renaissance party, tells France 24's Clovis Casali that there is little doubt French Prime Minister François Bayrou will lose Monday's no-confidence vote in parliament. But, she says, calling the vote was "absolutely necessary" as he seeks to reduce France's debt.
items.content: Eleonore Caroit, MP for French citizens living in Latin America and the Caribbean and a member of Emmanuel Macron's Renaissance party, tells France 24's Clovis Casali that there is little doubt French Prime Minister François Bayrou will lose Monday's no-confidence vote in parliament. But, she says, calling the vote was "absolutely necessary" as he seeks to reduce France's debt.

items.title: Veron: 'Distinguishing the real French political crisis from the lack of a immediate financial one'
items.standfirst: François Bayrou faces a crucial confidence vote just nine months into his tenure, plunging France into fresh political turmoil and heightening pressure on President Macron. Bayrou shocked allies by calling the vote himself, aiming to end a deadlock over his controversial €44 billion austerity budget. For historical context and in-depth analysis, FRANCE 24's Annette Young welcomes Nicolas Véron, French Economist and Senior Fellow at Bruegel and the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
items.content: François Bayrou faces a crucial confidence vote just nine months into his tenure, plunging France into fresh political turmoil and heightening pressure on President Macron. Bayrou shocked allies by calling the vote himself, aiming to end a deadlock over his controversial €44 billion austerity budget. For historical context and in-depth analysis, FRANCE 24's Annette Young welcomes Nicolas Véron, French Economist and Senior Fellow at Bruegel and the Peterson Institute for International Economics.

items.title: French PM says confidence vote 'a test of truth', warns of debt threat
items.standfirst: France's excessive debt pile is "life-threatening" for the country, Prime Minister Francois Bayrou said Monday as he defended billions of euros of budget cuts ahead of a confidence vote expected to bring down his government, which he labelled a "test of truth". His address, Bayrou's final chance to win lawmakers over, was repeatedly interrupted by heckling from opposition parties in a tense National Assembly chamber.
items.content: France's excessive debt pile is "life-threatening" for the country, Prime Minister Francois Bayrou said Monday as he defended billions of euros of budget cuts ahead of a confidence vote expected to bring down his government, which he labelled a "test of truth". His address, Bayrou's final chance to win lawmakers over, was repeatedly interrupted by heckling from opposition parties in a tense National Assembly chamber.

items.title: 'Very unlikely' Bayrou swayed any MPs in final speech before confidence vote
items.standfirst: France's over-indebtedness is putting its survival at stake, Prime Minister François Bayrou warned ahead of a confidence vote he is expected to lose later on Monday. But the prime minister's remarks, his last before the vote, are unlikely to have won over any lawmakers, says France 24's Clovis Casali.
items.content: France's over-indebtedness is putting its survival at stake, Prime Minister François Bayrou warned ahead of a confidence vote he is expected to lose later on Monday. But the prime minister's remarks, his last before the vote, are unlikely to have won over any lawmakers, says France 24's Clovis Casali.

items.title: Bayrou offers 'doom and gloom' in final speech before confidence vote
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister François Bayrou warned the country’s excessive debt pile is "life-threatening" as he made his final speech to parliament ahead of a confidence vote that he is widely expected to lose. France 24’s French politics editor Marc Perelman and international affairs editor offer their analysis of what was an often downbeat final address by the French PM.
items.content: French Prime Minister François Bayrou warned the country’s excessive debt pile is "life-threatening" as he made his final speech to parliament ahead of a confidence vote that he is widely expected to lose. France 24’s French politics editor Marc Perelman and international affairs editor offer their analysis of what was an often downbeat final address by the French PM.

items.title: French Parliament ousts second PM in less than a year, fueling instability
items.standfirst: France's National Assembly is set to vote for a motion of no confidence in François Bayrou, less than a year after they did the same for Michel Barnier.
items.content: France's National Assembly is set to vote for a motion of no confidence in François Bayrou, less than a year after they did the same for Michel Barnier.

items.title: French PM Bayrou ousted in no-confidence vote: What’s next?
items.standfirst: PM Francois Bayrou lost the vote, but a deadlock in Parliament means France might struggle to find a replacement.
items.content: PM Francois Bayrou lost the vote, but a deadlock in Parliament means France might struggle to find a replacement.

items.title: Is new alliance in works, extending from French Socialists, Ecologists, Communists to centre-right?
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister Francois Bayrou was set to fall in a confidence vote in parliament on Monday after just nine months in the job, sparking fresh political uncertainty for France and piling pressure on President Emmanuel Macron. Bayrou blindsided even his allies by calling a confidence vote to end a months-long standoff over his 44 billion euro austerity budget. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, FRANCE 24's Delano d'Souza welcomes Paul Smith, Associate Professor in French History and Politics at the University of Nottingham.
items.content: French Prime Minister Francois Bayrou was set to fall in a confidence vote in parliament on Monday after just nine months in the job, sparking fresh political uncertainty for France and piling pressure on President Emmanuel Macron. Bayrou blindsided even his allies by calling a confidence vote to end a months-long standoff over his 44 billion euro austerity budget. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, FRANCE 24's Delano d'Souza welcomes Paul Smith, Associate Professor in French History and Politics at the University of Nottingham.

items.title: REPLAY: French PM Bayrou makes final speech to parliament before confidence vote
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister François Bayrou made his final speech to parliament Monday ahead of a confidence vote in which his government is widely expected to be toppled. Defending the budget proposals that led to the vote, Bayrou warned France's excessive debt pile is "life-threatening" for the country. Watch his speech in full above.
items.content: French Prime Minister François Bayrou made his final speech to parliament Monday ahead of a confidence vote in which his government is widely expected to be toppled. Defending the budget proposals that led to the vote, Bayrou warned France's excessive debt pile is "life-threatening" for the country. Watch his speech in full above.

items.title: French PM loses confidence vote - as country's political crisis deepens
items.standfirst: France's prime minister has failed in a last-minute bid to save his job, with the country's National Assembly ousting him in a confidence vote.
items.content: France's prime minister has failed in a last-minute bid to save his job, with the country's National Assembly ousting him in a confidence vote.

ai_summary: French Prime Minister François Bayrou lost a confidence vote after nine months in office.
President Emmanuel Macron must find a fourth prime minister in twelve months.
The government collapsed after Bayrou's loss, plunging France into political crisis.
Bayrou will tender his resignation, creating fresh political turmoil.
Legislators toppled the government, creating a new crisis for the economy.

items.title: Gunmen kill at least six people at Jerusalem bus stop
items.standfirst: Two gunmen opened fire at a Jerusalem bus stop, killing at least six people and critically injuring seven others, emergency services said. The two attackers were “neutralized,” the police said. Hamas hailed the attack as "heroic" but did not claim responsibility.

items.title: Deadly protests erupt in Nepal over social media ban
items.standfirst: Multiple people were killed and dozens more were wounded in Nepal after protests erupted over the government's social media ban, authorities said. CBS News' Shanelle Kaul has the latest.
items.content: Multiple people were killed and dozens more were wounded in Nepal after protests erupted over the government's social media ban, authorities said. CBS News' Shanelle Kaul has the latest.

items.title: At least 19 killed in ‘gen Z’ protests against Nepal’s social media ban
items.standfirst: Many demonstrators say they are also on the streets over corruption and nepotism they allege is rampant At least 19 people have been killed during protests in Nepal over a government ban on dozens of online platforms including Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and X.The government has faced mounting criticism after imposing a ban on 26 prominent social media platforms and messaging apps last week because they had missed a deadline to register under new regulations. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.content: At least fourteen people were killed and dozens injured in Nepal’s Kathmandu during protests against the government’s decision to ban several social media platforms, local media reported.

items.title: At least 19 dead in Nepal protests over social media ban
items.standfirst: At least 19 people have been killed in Nepal as protesters clashed with police over a government decision to block 26 social media platforms, including Facebook, X and YouTube.
items.content: At least 19 people have been killed in Nepal as protesters clashed with police over a government decision to block 26 social media platforms, including Facebook, X and YouTube.

ai_summary: At least nineteen people have died in Nepal during protests.
Protests are over a government ban on social media platforms.
Demonstrators are also protesting corruption and nepotism.
Police used water cannons, batons, and rubber bullets on protesters.
The government banned 26 social media platforms for missing registration deadlines.

clusters.title: Supreme court lifts restrictions on Los Angeles immigration raids in win for Trump
clusters.neutral_headline: Supreme Court Lifts Restrictions on LA Immigration Raids

items.title: Supreme court lifts restrictions on Los Angeles immigration raids in win for Trump
items.standfirst: Conservative majority lifts restraining order from judge who found’roving patrols’ were conducting indiscriminate arrestsUS politics live – latest updatesFederal agents can resume sweeping immigration operations in Los Angeles after the US supreme court lifted an order barring the Donald Trump administration from stopping people solely based on their race, language or job.The court ruled in favor of Trump’s administration, granting a stay against a restraining order from another judge that found “roving patrols” of immigration agents were conducting indiscriminate arrests in LA. The ruling from the conservative majority is a win for the administration in its ongoing effort to enact mass deportations. Continue reading...
items.content: Conservative majority lifts restraining order from judge who found’roving patrols’ were conducting indiscriminate arrestsUS politics live – latest updatesFederal agents can resume sweeping immigration operations in Los Angeles after the US supreme court lifted an order barring the Donald Trump administration from stopping people solely based on their race, language or job.The court ruled in favor of Trump’s administration, granting a stay against a restraining order from another judge that found “roving patrols” of immigration agents were conducting indiscriminate arrests in LA. The ruling from the conservative majority is a win for the administration in its ongoing effort to enact mass deportations. Continue reading...

items.content: US top court says that immigration agents can stop people based solely on their race, language or job.

items.title: US Supreme Court allows Trump’s controversial immigration raids to continue
items.standfirst: Decision effectively allows immigration agents to use racial profiling to detain people, greenlighting sweeping raids.
items.content: Decision effectively allows immigration agents to use racial profiling to detain people, greenlighting sweeping raids.

items.title: Supreme Court lifts restrictions on LA immigration stops set after agents swept up US citizens

ai_summary: The Supreme Court lifted restrictions on Los Angeles immigration stops.
The court ruled in favor of the Trump administration.
Immigration agents can resume sweeping operations in Los Angeles.
The court granted a stay against a restraining order.
The order barred stopping people based on race, language, or job.

items.title: South Koreans face shock and confusion after worker detentions at Georgia Hyundai plant

items.content: South Korea’s foreign minister is en route to the U.S. to finalize steps for the return home of several hundred workers detained in a massive immigration raid in Georgia.

items.title: South Korea says it is helping citizens return voluntarily after huge Hyundai raid
items.standfirst: The South Korean government said Monday that it was arranging for hundreds of its nationals to leave the United States voluntarily after they were detained in an immigration raid on a Hyundai facility in Georgia that has strained relations with the key U.S. ally
items.content: The South Korean government said Monday that it was arranging for hundreds of its nationals to leave the United States voluntarily after they were detained in an immigration raid on a Hyundai facility in Georgia that has strained relations with the key U.S. ally

items.content: Some 400 US agents took part in the immigration raid on the Hyundai facility, detaining hundreds of workers, many South Korean nationals.

ai_summary: South Korean workers were detained in a Georgia Hyundai plant raid.

clusters.title: Trump asks Supreme Court to allow billions in foreign aid cuts
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Asks Supreme Court to Cut Foreign Aid

items.title: Trump asks Supreme Court to allow billions in foreign aid cuts
items.standfirst: The administration is seeking an emergency order as it tries to claw back funds allocated by Congress.
items.content: The administration is seeking an emergency order as it tries to claw back funds allocated by Congress.

items.title: Trump asks Supreme Court to let it cut billions in foreign aid
items.standfirst: Request comes after an appeals court orders Trump to distribute the congressionally approved funds.
items.content: Request comes after an appeals court orders Trump to distribute the congressionally approved funds.

items.title: Trump administration seeks Supreme Court order to maintain foreign aid spending freeze
items.standfirst: The Trump administration on Monday requested an emergency order from the Supreme Court to uphold its decision to withhold nearly $5 billion in foreign aid. The move follows a federal judge’s ruling that the administration’s budget maneouvre – known as a "pocket rescission" – likely violates the law as it bypasses Congress’s authority over spending.
items.content: The Trump administration on Monday requested an emergency order from the Supreme Court to uphold its decision to withhold nearly $5 billion in foreign aid. The move follows a federal judge’s ruling that the administration’s budget maneouvre – known as a "pocket rescission" – likely violates the law as it bypasses Congress’s authority over spending.

ai_summary: The Trump administration is seeking an emergency order from the Supreme Court.
The administration wants to withhold nearly $5 billion in foreign aid.
An appeals court ordered Trump to distribute the congressionally approved funds.
The administration's move follows a federal judge's ruling.
